result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality] and Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality] and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality] was dismissed by the court.

  • Joshua W. Helgemo was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Joshua W. Helgemo was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).
  • Joshua W. Helgemo was found guilty of Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 343.44(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Pay fine and costs totaling $3,264.00.  To be paid during probation on schedule arranged by the defendant and the agent. 
If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Do not operate a vehicle without a valid driver's license.

Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent. 
Provide a DNA sample and pay the surcharge.

Statement Regarding Recusal - Molepski, Jr/Judge Finn
Associated with Charge #1

Defendant Joshua W. Helgemo in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
All files heard: 14CF267, 14CF366, 14CT122, 14CT123

2:36 p.m.   Court calls the case. 

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.
Parties are prepared to proceed without a PSI. 

Atty Kryshak received a copy of the information and waives its reading in 14CF267.

Defendant enters a plea of:  14CF267 Counts 1, 3 and 4 - NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).
Defendant agrees this will result in his 4th conviction for OWI and 2nd conviction for OAR. 
Defendant further agrees with prior convictions. 

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty 14CF267 Counts 1, 3 & 4.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
14CF267 Count 2 is dismissed.
14CF267 Counts 5, 6 and 7 are dismissed and read-in.
14CF366, 14CT122, 14CT123 are dismissed and read-in. 

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Kryshak makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
14CF267 Count 1 - 
Determinate sentence in Prison of 4 years with 2 years Initial Confinement followed by 2 years Extended Supervision.  - STAYED -
Placed on probation for a period of 24 months:
Serve 150 days jail. 
Sentence to commence within 60 days. 
Report today for start date. 
Huber for going to work and any AODA treatment. 
Pay fine and costs totaling $3,264.00. To be paid during probation on schedule arranged by defendant and the agent.
Pay blood draw fee of $26.45.
Provide a DNA sample and pay the surcharge. 
36 months revocation  Revocation is retroactive to the date of the administrative suspension from the Dept. of Transportation
36 months IID, effective today. 
DOT assessment.
Any bonds on deposit are to be applied. 
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Do not operate a vehicle without a valid driver's license.
AODA and comply with treatment recommendations.
Maintain fulltime employment.
Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent.

14CF267 Count 3 - 
Determinate sentence in Prison of 2 years with 1 year Initial Confinement followed by 1 year Extended Supervision, concurrent with count 1.  - STAYED -
Placed on probation for a period of 24 months, concurrent:
Comply with conditions on Count 1. 
Pay costs including the DNA surcharge.  

14CF267 Count 4 - 
Serve 20 days in jail, concurrent with conditional jail time in Count 1. 
Same huber privileges are granted. 
Pay costs including the DNA surcharge.

If revoked, conditions of extended supervision are the same as those ordered for probation. 

Atty Kryshak asks for Electronic Monitor. 
BY THE COURT:  Court denies the Electronic Monitor. 

Defendant questions the Court re: Good Time Credit. 
Court indicates it is under Good Time Credit.
Plea/sentencing hearing on February 17, 2015 at 02:30 pm.

Pre-trial conference on January 12, 2015 at 08:30 am.

Arraignment on September 15, 2014 at 10:00 am.

Defendant Joshua W. Helgemo in court with attorney Sean Drury. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions the Defendant regarding Waiver of Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 
Information filed.
